snippet: Tule elk in a refuge have been dying off while a thriving herd outside it has encroached on pastures, rekindling a dispute over the management of the creatures.
abstract: Debate over management of indigenous tule elk population in California has cropped up again due to National Park Service survey finding that 250 elk living in penned-off reserve died between 2012 and 2014, while elk outside reserve have thrived; ranchers in Point Reyes peninsula complain that free-roaming elk are consuming drought-limited forage used by their herds, and question why elk within penned-off reserve do not have sufficient access to water.
lead_paragraph: Tule elk in a refuge have been dying off while a thriving herd outside it has encroached on pastures, rekindling a dispute over the management of the creatures.

headline.main: Roaming Elk at Point Reyes Bedevil Ranchers in California
headline.print_headline: While Protected Elk Dwindle, Wild Herds Bedevil Ranchers
